intro: Alaida, commonly known as the "ghost flower," is a unique plant native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the genus Alaja in the family Apocynaceae, characterized by its striking, bioluminescent flowers that emit a faint glow at night. The plant has adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments through specialized root systems and water-storing tissues. Its flowers bloom only during specific lunar phases, adding to its mystique.
